title: Evolution of the Topology of High-voltage Electricity Network

author: Lubos Buzna, Department of Humanities and Social Sciences, Chair of Sociology, in particular of Modeling and Simulation, ETH Zurich

segmentation: I'm going to present our work where we have evaluated the topology of.
French high voltage electricity network.

This work was done together with my colleague Lymore Sokurov and we were supervised by Professor Deer Camp, helping financially were supported from Iris Project which was introduced today morning by Walter Schmidt.
There appeared in last years in the network literature several papers.

Comparing the contemporary topologies of high voltage networks in different countries and our interest in this study was to look how where these statistical properties of network topology changing during that.
I'm.
Plan of my presentation after a short introduction I will present the data we have analyzed and then our read our results on network growth rate and evolution of networks.
Topological properties.
To conclude, I will summarize our.
Findings.
Electrical power grid is a very large system and it's one of the most important critical infrastructures.
It's composed from many different components.
Electrical energy is produced by generating units.
And it consumed by many end users.
Generation and consumption are connected by electrical network.
Electrical network is a hearer hickle system composed from many different levels.
Here are two main levels, transmission network and distribution network.
And in this study, we have evaluated the topology of French transmission network many functionalities of transmission network in general are to transport the energy across the country transport.
Of energy between the countries over a long distances.
And in the case of emergencies, it serves as a backup system for.
Neighboring countries.
The data we have analyzed.
We have analyzed the network or the high voltage network of runs which works at the voltage levels of 400 KV.
This network was introduced in the year 1960.
And before the highest voltage level was 220 kW.
We have studied this data for the time period between the night between the year 1960 and the year 2000 and in total we had 21 different snapshots of the network taken in B annual time steps.
This data were retrieved from the French electricity network operator RT Web page and they are publicly.
Every able.
We represented this network as a graph composed from nodes and links, and here in this first figure we have analyzed the growth rate of such network in terms of nodes.
Links and lines linked.
As we can see, this growth is far from being linear process and in rough outline it can be characterized by this first.
Relatively slowly liner growing phase followed by very intensive and rapid growth and it ends up with a saturation phase where at the end the network is almost not changing or not growing too.
Be more precise.
It was behind the scope of our study tool to analyze what are the reasons for this kind of grow.
But however we took look at some.

Indicators which we believe could have some effect or some influence on this network growth right here in this figure is depicted the overall consumption of electrical energy in France, export generation and import.
And here on the left hand side is a population.
Number of installed nuclear reactors and gross domestic product per capita.
In France, the most of the energy I think it's about 78% is produced from nuclear energy and also when we look on the number of installed nuclear reactors.
It resembles mostly the growing rate of the network also, except this last phase.
This trend in the GDP seems to be similar to the growing rate of network.
Except that we have also studied some.
Come on properties of the network.
Here in this figure is the relation between the number of nodes and number of links in the network, how it was changing in the time.
Here we found a linear relation, which implies that the mean node connectivity of this network was almost no changing in the during this evolution process.
This linear relation implies the value or.
Or means also account constant mean, no degree of about value 2.8.
It's quite interesting that exactly this value 2.8 was reported in several papers as a.
As a mean note, connectivity of several contemporary.
High voltage network topologies.
And also this mean node connectivity is constant while.
As you can see here, the node degree distribution is changing quite signific.
Bentley I will teach.
Network topology is also known as a small word graph.
Here we studied the evolution of this property in the graph.
This property.
This property is defined based on the comparison of this graph with equivalent random graph.
So graph which have the same number of nodes and edges.

And we say that the graph is a small world when the average shortest path in this graph is smaller than in this random graph, and when it's clustering is much larger than the clustering of this equivalent random graph.
Based on this criteria, we can see here that.
High Voltage Network gained the small world property only in the last approximately 15 years.
Here is a more detailed view on clustering coefficient clustering coefficient for node I.
Gives information or gives probability that also the node the neighbors of these nodes are connected.
Here we can see that during the evolution, the clustering coefficient of.
The network was growing until the year 1996.
Then in this year it reached maximum and then it was decreasing.
Until the year 2.
1000 the next property we have studied is between us centrality.

This measure gives an idea about the distribution of load of loads among the links under a very simplified assumptions, we assume that between each pair of node we have the same exchange of load over a shortest path.
Here I should mention that the graphs we have evaluated are a multiple.
Graph or multi graph.
So it means that they have also some parallel double or triple lines and we treated them.
In the same way like impedance in electrical circuit.
When we look on the network from here 2000 then we will find their 272 non node pairs which are connected out of them are 11 doublings and free triple rings.
If we assume that this parallel lines were built from capacity reasons.
Then this between US centrality gives us some kind of correlation between.
Load on the link and it's between a centrality here.
In this table we have ordered the node pairs according to between a centrality and for example here in the year 2000.
Within the first 13 connected node pairs we found.
Seven doublings and one.
Tripling here is a more detailed view on the.
Age between its centrality.
Here I should say that this one car here represents the betweenness centrality's for all nodes in a given year and we have ordered them ascendingly ascendingly.
Here we can see that.
Age between a centrality is decreasing in time, and the network is becoming to be more homogeneous in.
Respect.
And lost the flight which I want to present is the evaluation of node information centrality.
Node information centrality is a measure measure which can give an rough idea about the sensitivity of the network to the node removal.
It's defined as a relative change in a graph efficiency when the graph efficiency is defined by this formula.
Where this DJ is.
Length of the shortest path between.
Do note Inj here is a mean information centrality.
With this figure says that the sensitivity of the network.
Real respect to node removal was decreasing over the whole studying.
Also the.
Very critical points are disappearing from the network and the network is becoming to be more homogeneous.
Respect.
And now just summary of our results.
In this paper we have studied the growth of French high voltage electricity network we have found.
Non linear growth of this network.
We found constant mean no degree during the power grid construction process, while the node degree distribution changes.
In this case, network was growing until it gained a small world property.
Information centrality and betweenness centrality measure measures were continuously improving with time and clustering coefficients.
Increase only up to the year 1996 and later on there started to decrease, which can mean some kind of.
Negative development, but this is hard to predict based on a such.
Simple data.
Thank you for your attention.
Do you have any?
Company.
Any connections and why is the change of degree distribution have same constantly draw connection to the top of an bed?
There might be some optimization that contains in the sense that every degrees based constants or the number of links essentially moving away the number of winding noise increases.
I don't know.
Yeah, this distribution is changing, but the constant mean no degree.

Seems to be constant and yeah, to be to be honest, I still don't know why, but I don't know why it is like this this this maybe could be explained by some models which would try to reproduce this dynamic.
How this network is growing, but we were not doing this.
Actually, the operators never could tell you why this is my technique cause he saw a simulated making medium voltage network said they avoid.
Note that only one connected that simply because of the celebrated in lines one, yeah.
So there might be a medium again engineering technical explanation probably.
Yeah, I agree, but I haven't studied this.
This mechanisms which are behind.
Thank you.
